tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: Game of Thrones, Episode 8.02: How to Kill Wights, White Walkers--and the Night King
title: Game of Thrones, Episode 8.02: How to Kill Wights, White Walkers--and the Night King
body:
Back in Episode 7.06, “Beyond the Wall,” Jon, Jorah, and Beric had a conversation about siring:  when Jon killed a White Walker, the wights with him immediately dropped dead as well.  As the army of the living plan their defence in Episode 8.02, Jon brings this phenomenon up again.  

For my new followers, here’s what I wrote back in 2017 about the alchemical origins of this idea.  

*******************************************

In Episode 7.06 (”Beyond the Wall”) Jon, Jorah and Beric have a conversation just before the lake refreezes and the wights launch their final attack.  Jorah asks why, after Jon killed their White Walker leader in an earlier skirmish, almost all the wights spontaneously died.  Jon speculates that perhaps it’s because the WW had “made” them.  Beric then suggests that maybe the way to destroy them all would be to kill the Night King, since HE made all of them.  The conversation goes in another direction at this point, but it seems safe to assume that GOT has established a kind of “siring” here.  

In vampire lore a vampire “sires”–creates–a new vampire by sharing blood with his victim.  In GOT the Night King sires wights by resurrecting the dead–and the resulting zombified people and creatures have distinctive ice blue eyes.  

But where does the idea come from that if you kill the sire, the zombies he has created die as well?  It’s part of vampire lore and GRRM could have picked it up from that.  But Polidori’s The Vampyre gets us back only to 1816; does the idea go back any earlier? Yes! In alchemy, of course.  In Michael Maier’s Atalanta fugiens (1618) we get this fascinating image and explanation:



The four men on the left represent the Four Elements.  The first man carries two balls of Fire; the second a ball of Wind, i.e., Air; the third is throwing a stream of Water, and the fourth is holding a ball of Earth. The title is:

<Si de quattuor unum Occidas, subito mortuus omnis erit.>

Which translates as

If you kill one of the four, immediately all will die.

Since alchemists believed that every substance in the world consists of some combination of the Four Elements, the destruction of one causes the death of all.

**********************************************

So back to Episode 8.02.  

By Episode 8.02, Jon has incorporated Beric’s siring idea–kill the “maker” and the rest fall–into his battle plan.  As he explains to the Winterfell war council, “The Night King made them all. They follow his command. If he falls….getting to him may be our best chance.”

Bran asks the obvious follow-up question: How do you kill the NK?  Will dragonfire stop him? Jon doesn’t know: “No one’s ever tried.”  Still, we see the basic outlines of the battle plan for Episode 8.03 unfold here.  Hold the AOTD off as long as you can while you focus on getting the NK.  

Jenny and Her Ghosts

Just one more comment on Episode 8.02 before I post about Jonerys.  Alchemy stories often feature epic songs–Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, and ASOIAF all include song texts.  We have a particularly memorable one in this episode–Diwadi’s setting of the text of “Jenny and Her Ghosts.”   

It may be sheer coincidence, but one of the most influential alchemy texts, Atalanta fugiens, included not just texts and illustrations, but music.  It has often been called the first multimedia production in history.  You can listen to the music that accompanies each emblem, on YT.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O5f9WkPNbBM&list=PLvdLjWKhtJcOfjQAE-Fxs_sfhIHfPQ4xT&index=1

summary: Theon defending Winterfell: The redemption we deserve
title: Theon defending Winterfell: The redemption we deserve
body:
Related post: Theon’s homecoming journey

“Am I your brother, now and always?”

“Now and always.”

“My sword is yours, in victory and defeat, from this day until my last day.”

Theon to Robb, 1x10

So Theon’s return to Winterfell in episode 8x02 turned out to be much more beautiful and touching than I expected. I bursted into tears the moment Sansa ran into him, offered him a warm embrace and he hugged her back. The emotional weight of that scene, I could find no word to describe it. Alfie and Sophie totally nailed it with their brilliant acting. To me, it’s the best moment in S8 so far, because it is profoundly touching and very multi-layered. It’s not only about the bond between Theon and Sansa, but involves other the important people in their lives, both alive (Bran and Jon) and deceased (Ned, Robb, Rickon, Ser Rodrick, Maester Luwin). That’s the aspect I like about GoT, where characters are interrelated. Those who passed away still have an impact on the lives and decisions of those who remain. And in that sense, they are never forgotten.

Gif: thesistersstark

The lie he told himself

Despite his status as a ward, Theon was treated with kindness at Winterfell, and Robb considered him his best friend. But there was still distance between them.  Everytime Theon tried to prove himself a member of the Stark family, Robb unintentionally reminded him that he was not.

When Theon told Robb to wage a war on the Lannisters for attacking Ned, Robb told him it was not Theon’s duty to represent the Starks because it was not his House. 

When Theon shoot the arrow at the wilding who captures Bran, Robb was mad at him fearing that it would have endangered Bran’s life if he missed the target, and told him he didn’t have the right to carry such risky act. Theon was offended, because it was implied that Theon didn’t have the right to do so, because he was not considered as Bran’s brother.

Source: rebloggy

Robb didn’t mean to hurt Theon, but why was Theon upset about it? Growing up with the Stark kids, Theon longed to be one of them. He went with Robb to war, fought alongside Robb, declared Robb his King and offered to help bring Robb the Iron Fleet. He did all this to be accepted as a true family member.

When Theon was back to Pyke to persuade his father to join Robb’s side, Balon Greyjoy got mad at him for being more a Stark than a Greyjoy, and forced him to choose side. Theon was conflicted. He was about to send a letter to Robb to inform his best friend about his father’s plan.

Robb,
I hope this reaches you in time. Father has rejected your offer and plans to attack the North, raiding the shores and taking Deepwood Motte. Mobilize your army and make for the North before it’s too late. I’ll write again when I can.
Theon

Gif: rebloggy

But, in the end, he burnt the letter away, convincing himself that he could only be a Greyjoy since the Starks never saw him as one of them.

I could never be a Stark. Robb Stark always reminded me of that. […] It’s Ironborn, that I was born to be. (Theon to Ramsay, 3x04)

When Theon sacked Winterfell and proclaimed himself the Prince of Winterfell, Maester Luwin tried to appeal to the goodness in him by reminding him that Ned had gone out of his way to make Winterfell a home for Theon. He responded aggressively.

Yes, my captors were so very kind to me. You love reminding me of that. Everyone in this frozen pile of shit has always loved reminding me of that. You know what it’s like to be told how lucky you are to be someone’s prisoner? To be told how much you owe them? And then to go back home to your real father… (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But was it true? Or Theon was just lying to himself to make his act of betrayal less painful? Maester Luwin saw through him and told him he was just pretending to be a ruthless man, when in fact he was not. Not yet.

Deep down, Theon knew he loved the Stark and Winterfell as his family and his home, worsening the pains and guilt he bore in his heart.

I know who you are. I know what you are. Now answer my question. Why do you love the Starks?

“I…” Theon put a gloved hand against a pilar. “… I wanted to be one of them…” (The Turncloak, A Dance with Dragons)

His weight of guilt has been lifted

Right after Theon sacked Winterfell and committed horrible crimes, he started to feel guilty and horrified by his own acts. 

I’ve done a lot, haven’t I? Things I’ve never imagined myself doing. (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But he continued to act ruthlessly to avoid being seen as weak. 

Being surrounded by Ramsay’s force, he was urged by Maester Luwin to escape Winterfell via the passageway and join the Night’s Watch where all his crimes would be forgiven. Theon declined, fearing that if he appeared in Castle Black, Jon would slit his throat while he was sleeping. Theon believed that he had gone too far to come back. 

 After helping Sansa escape, he was also advised to join the Night’s Watch. He once again refused, thinking of himself as beyone repair and not worthy of forgiveness. He feared that if he showed up in Castle Black, Jon would kill him right away. Theon was not yet ready to face the judgement for his crimes.

Luckily for him, it was not as bad as he expected when he finally met Jon. ‘Though being angry with Theon at first, Jon appreciated what he did for Sansa and restrained himself from doing any harm to the betrayer. Jon finally forgave Theon and acknowledged him as a Stark, thus uplifting the emotional weight of guilt upon him. Jon’s kind words encouraged Theon to overcome his fear to go rescue Yara.

Theon had a safer option

After rescuing Yara, Theon could have chosen to go to the Iron Islands with his sister and take back their home, wait out the winter in a place the Dead cannot go. He said himself they should prepare a place for Dany to retreat in case they couldn’t hold the North and he would follow his sister’s command. But his heart was actually elsewhere. At Winterfell, where the fighting is thickest. Yara noticed the wish in her brother’s eyes, and she let him go where he wanted.

Gif: jaimelannistecr

He goes to Winterfell for the memory of Ned, fighting alongside the children of his foster father

No matter how Theon felt bitter about the Starks for being a ward in Winterfell, he admited that he saw Ned as his real father. 

When Theon faced Jon in Dragonstone, he was reminded that Ned was a father to him more than his biological father Balon ever was, that Theon had betrayed the memory of Ned.

However, Jon also offered an act of kindness and encouragement to Theon, he affirmed that Ned is always part of Theon, just like he’s a part of Jon. That was a huge morale boost for Theon.

Coming back to Winterfell, to the place that was his home for a handful of time, Theon is ready to defend the legacy of the honorable man who brought him up, alongside Ned’s children.

He is going to atone his betrayal to Robb by defending Robb’s brother(s) and sister(s)

Robb and Theon were more than just friends. They were almost like brothers. Theon followed Robb into the war and declared Robb his King. At the beginning, he whole-heartedly wanted to avenge Ned with Robb. He offered Robb his father’s Iron Fleet.

But he broke his promised and betrayed Robb’s trust. He led the Ironborn’s attack to Winterfell, sacked the castle and captured Bran and Rickon. His betrayal was the start for a chain of events that led to Robb’s eventual demise.

Robb was shocked, heart-broken, and angry when he learned about the news.

Theon then paid a high price for such crime. He was tortured by Ramsay and forced to abandon his identity. But he still remembered who he was, and was totally devastated when hearing of Robb’s death from Ramsay.

Oh, that’s right, Reek. Robb Stark is dead. Sorry. I know he was like a brother to you, but my father put a knife through his heart. How do you feel about that? (Ramsay to Theon, 4x02)

And Robb. Robb had been more a a brother to Theon than any son born of Balon Greyjoy’s loins. Murdered at the Red Wedding, butchered by the Freys. I should have been with him. Where was I? I should have died with him. (Theon, A Dance with Dragons)

When Robb was still alive, he was very protective of Bran. So I’m very glad that Theon volunteered to stay with Bran in the godswood to wait for the Night King. He continued what Robb left incomplete: protecting his little brother. 

Gif: rebloggy

Theon can also help to keep Sansa safe, the mission that Robb couldn’t finish. Robb started the war to free his father and sisters, but until Robb’s last days, Sansa was still a captive in King’s Landing. And she wept so much over Robb’s depature, even endured the pain of seeing her brother’s death ridiculed during the royal wedding. Sansa and Theon’s love and grief for Robb is one of the main factors that bond them together.

An apology to Ser Rodrik

One of the most heart-breaking moments in season 2 was when Theon beheaded Ser Rodrik. Coming to defend Winterfell against the Dead would be the most meaningful thing Theon can do to atone the crime he committed to the faithful master-at-arms of Winterfell.

Maester Luwin’s good heart finally pays off

In a brutal world like GoT, where the most ruthless and cunning people usually win, good, honest and compassionate people tend to be seen as weak, idiots and losers. But if in the end, Theon proves that a broken man like him can eventually amend his mistakes and become a brave and honorable person, the first person we should thank is Maester Luwin. He was very patient and never gave up on Theon, and used every chance possible to remind the heir of the Iron Islands of the goodness inside him. Maester Luwin even tried to interfere when Theon was beaten down and captured by his men to be handed to Ramsay, and was fatally wounded as a result. Doing the right thing, be the right kind of person is how Theon can pay tribute to Maester Luwin’s kindness.

Moreover, Bran was the Stark kid Maester Luwin spent the most time with. He had a lot of affection for Bran and tried to groom the little boy into a good lord. In his dying breath, the maester reminded Bran that there was still hope as long as he lived. Maester Luwin could rest in peace now if he knows the man whose heart he risked his life to stir back to goodness is now defending the boy who he loved and protect ‘till his last breath. 

To right the wrong he did to Bran

Bran always knew how to ask the right question. With braveness, he looked Theon in the eyes and asked if his surrogate brother in fact hated the Starks all the time. (Honestly, Bran looked like a professor asking his student a difficult exam question. 😂) It shook Theon, because no matter how resentful he was, he still cared for the Starks and longed to be one of them. But he had gone too far, so he kept his mask on, and tried to be as ruthless as possible.

Needless to say, Theon owed Bran an apology for taking Bran’s home and brutally chopping off Ser Rodrik’s head in front of his two little foster brothers, ignoring Bran crying and begging hopelessly.

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

This was perhaps Bran’s most traumatic experience up to that point, losing his home, being betrayed by someone he trusted like a family member, and seeing his faithful man horribly murder before his eyes. All in a day! Too much for a child as his age to bear.

At last, Theon has the courage to face the ghosts of his past crimes and amend for the horrible things he did by offering Bran his protection.

Gif: natalieedormer

For the love of Sansa

Is Theon in love Sansa? Since season 5, when their paths cross at Winterfell, this question has been raised. Even ‘though giving Sansa Jeyne’s Winterfell storyline was a divergence from the books, I beleve the show writers did this for a reason: to highlight Sansa’s relationship with both Jon and Theon. 

Like Jon, Theon longed to be seen as part of the Stark family and he endured the pain of feeling unworthy and being an outsider. As a child, he even dreamed of having Sansa’s hands in marriage, so that he could become Ned’s son.

He remembered a time when he had thought that Lord Eddard Stark might marry him to Sansa and claim him for a son, but that had only been a child’s fancy. (Reek, A Dance with Dragons)

Although it is not apparent in the books about Theon’s fondness for Sansa herself, the show made it quite obvious about his deep affection for her. Theon was totally broken and scared under Ramsay’s hands, he allowed himself to be treated like a loyal dog to his master, until Sansa came back to his life. She reminded him of who he was, his pride as a Greyjoy, that he was part of the Stark family. Gradually, she was able to convince him to pick up his strength again and break free from their abuser. 

Sansa has made the impossible possible. Theon’s embarked on his redemption journey since then. It tells how much of an influence she has on Theon. No matter what kind of love it is, familial, friendship, or romantic, it has to be really strong and true to create such a momentum for change in a person.

They’ve been through their darkest and hardest time together.

Gif: nemomurphy

Since Sansa had Brienne and Podrick by her side, Theon left halfway to go back to the Iron Islands. He was not confident that he could ever keep her safer than her family (Jon) could, and he was afraid that Jon would kill him right the moment he stepped through the gate of Castle Black.

Gif: nnymeros

Before they parted ways, Sansa gave Theon a hug as an act of forgiveness. She was the first Stark to forgive Theon for the crimes he committed to her family, and this meant a lot to him.

When Theon met up with Jon at Dragonstone, the first question he asked was about Sansa. He is concerned about his incomplete mission to protect her.

Gif: nnymeros

The thing I do for love

Gif: nnymeros

It was an emotional comeback for Theon. He is no longer the coward who is always scared and runs away. He chooses to face his past crimes and the people he wronged. He chooses to fight in the most dangerous place in the world, over his own safety in a place the Dead cannot reach.

For the love of Winterfell, his once home, the place where he grew up with his surrogate brothers and sisters, where he tasted his short-lived victory after sacking the castle and proclaiming himself Prince of Winterfell, where he suffered the worst traumas of his life as a punishment for his crimes.

For the love of Ned, the father figure who raised him to be an honorable person.

For the love of Robb, his brother and his King, who he swore to fight for, and yet betrayed.

For the love of Bran, the little brother he once wronged,

For the love of Sansa, the sister who’s been through the hardest time with him, who helped bring back his sense of self.

For the respect of Jon, the friend who always chooses to do the right thing in his eyes.

For Rickon, Maester Luwin, Ser Rodrik, and the two farm boys he murdered, …

There was a time it mattered for Theon to define himself as a Stark or a Greyjoy, which side he should choose, but once he is sure of his heart, it doesn’t matter how he calls himself anymore. What really matters is who he truly cares for, and who he wants to protect. That’s the power of love, the power that mends a broken person, the power that inspires and transforms him into a brave one.

If a man knows what he is, and remains true to himself, the choice is no choice at all. (Stannis to Shireen, 5x09)

Welcome back home, brother. Welcome back to the pack.

Gif: thesistersstark

Sansa was very sad when Theon didn’t go with her to the Wall. Now he’s back to her side in a difficult time when they are at the edge of life and death, Sansa rejoices. For her, it’s like getting back a long lost family member. The moment she embraced Theon, he was not only forgiven. He was accepted back to the pack, despite being no true wolf.

From now on, he was no longer seen as an outsider. He has the right to defend Winterfell and its people like a true Stark. He has become one of them. That’s the kind of acceptance he longed for.

Why do you love the Starks?

I wanted to be one of them.

Now you are truly one of them, Theon. 😢

Trust each other

Theon volunteered to be with Bran in the godswood to protect him against the Night King. Bran accepted this offer, showing that he already forgave Theon and now he entrusted Theon with his life. This is a very dangerous task for both of them. 

Gif:  stormborns

Gif: gameofthronesdaily

When Theon offered this, Sansa’s reaction was clearly in focus. Sansa never saw the Dead herself like Jon or Bran, but she could imagine how risky it is to face the Night King. She was worrying for Bran, and for Theon. 

Gif: yol101

Later on, during the last calm moment before the storm, Sansa and Theon were shown having soup outside together. Many audience interpreted it as romantic, but I see it as trust, comfort and empathy. There are certain things that only these two could understand and share with one another, because they suffered the same. To Sansa, Theon is like a brother, a best friend, who shares with her the most traumatic secrets. The affection Theon has for Sansa, I believe it’s a mix of familial love, profound friendship, adoration and a hint of romantic feelings for a lady. This is a deep, unique and special kind of bond that goes beyond pure romance.

This is just my interpretation: I do think that this scene is not only about Sansa and Theon alone. Coupling with her concerned look during the war council (which was clearly in focus), Sansa is worried that Bran is putting himself in an extremely dangerous position, and Theon will be the one guarding Bran. So Sansa is entrusting Theon to protect their little brother. From her look, I would read it as “I trust you. Please keep Bran safe for me. And keep yourself safe too.” Theon finally has the right to protect Bran as a brother. He will do his best to keep Bran unharmed, Robb can rest in peace now.

Gif: captainmarvels

My sword is yours, in victory and defeat, from this day until my last day.

Am I your brother, now and always?
Now and always.

Theon has been through an incredible redemption arc. He’s grown from one of the most disliked characters to one of the most compelling characters. His journey proves that anyone can be forgiven, if he contrites and tries his best to amend for his mistakes. I hope that we would see more of the heroic acts from Theon, for as long as possible. After all the pains GoT have us endure, seeing a character like Theon stand up and be back to the good side is what the audience rightly deserve.

Related post: Theon’s homecoming journey

“Am I your brother, now and always?”

“Now and always.”

“My sword is yours, in victory and defeat, from this day until my last day.”

Theon to Robb, 1x10

So Theon’s return to Winterfell in episode 8x02 turned out to be much more beautiful and touching than I expected. I bursted into tears the moment Sansa ran into him, offered him a warm embrace and he hugged her back. The emotional weight of that scene, I could find no word to describe it. Alfie and Sophie totally nailed it with their brilliant acting. To me, it’s the best moment in S8 so far, because it is profoundly touching and very multi-layered. It’s not only about the bond between Theon and Sansa, but involves other the important people in their lives, both alive (Bran and Jon) and deceased (Ned, Robb, Rickon, Ser Rodrick, Maester Luwin). That’s the aspect I like about GoT, where characters are interrelated. Those who passed away still have an impact on the lives and decisions of those who remain. And in that sense, they are never forgotten.

Gif: thesistersstark

And in that sense, they are never forgotten.

Gif: thesistersstark

[[MORE]]

The lie he told himself

Despite his status as a ward, Theon was treated with kindness at Winterfell, and Robb considered him his best friend. But there was still distance between them.  Everytime Theon tried to prove himself a member of the Stark family, Robb unintentionally reminded him that he was not.

When Theon told Robb to wage a war on the Lannisters for attacking Ned, Robb told him it was not Theon’s duty to represent the Starks because it was not his House. 

When Theon shoot the arrow at the wilding who captures Bran, Robb was mad at him fearing that it would have endangered Bran’s life if he missed the target, and told him he didn’t have the right to carry such risky act. Theon was offended, because it was implied that Theon didn’t have the right to do so, because he was not considered as Bran’s brother.

Source: rebloggy

Robb didn’t mean to hurt Theon, but why was Theon upset about it? Growing up with the Stark kids, Theon longed to be one of them. He went with Robb to war, fought alongside Robb, declared Robb his King and offered to help bring Robb the Iron Fleet. He did all this to be accepted as a true family member.

When Theon was back to Pyke to persuade his father to join Robb’s side, Balon Greyjoy got mad at him for being more a Stark than a Greyjoy, and forced him to choose side. Theon was conflicted. He was about to send a letter to Robb to inform his best friend about his father’s plan.

Robb,
I hope this reaches you in time. Father has rejected your offer and plans to attack the North, raiding the shores and taking Deepwood Motte. Mobilize your army and make for the North before it’s too late. I’ll write again when I can.
Theon

Gif: rebloggy

But, in the end, he burnt the letter away, convincing himself that he could only be a Greyjoy since the Starks never saw him as one of them.

I could never be a Stark. Robb Stark always reminded me of that. […] It’s Ironborn, that I was born to be. (Theon to Ramsay, 3x04)

When Theon sacked Winterfell and proclaimed himself the Prince of Winterfell, Maester Luwin tried to appeal to the goodness in him by reminding him that Ned had gone out of his way to make Winterfell a home for Theon. He responded aggressively.

Yes, my captors were so very kind to me. You love reminding me of that. Everyone in this frozen pile of shit has always loved reminding me of that. You know what it’s like to be told how lucky you are to be someone’s prisoner? To be told how much you owe them? And then to go back home to your real father… (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But was it true? Or Theon was just lying to himself to make his act of betrayal less painful? Maester Luwin saw through him and told him he was just pretending to be a ruthless man, when in fact he was not. Not yet.

Deep down, Theon knew he loved the Stark and Winterfell as his family and his home, worsening the pains and guilt he bore in his heart.

I know who you are. I know what you are. Now answer my question. Why do you love the Starks?

“I…” Theon put a gloved hand against a pilar. “… I wanted to be one of them…” (The Turncloak, A Dance with Dragons)

His weight of guilt has been lifted

Right after Theon sacked Winterfell and committed horrible crimes, he started to feel guilty and horrified by his own acts. 

I’ve done a lot, haven’t I? Things I’ve never imagined myself doing. (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But he continued to act ruthlessly to avoid being seen as weak. 

Being surrounded by Ramsay’s force, he was urged by Maester Luwin to escape Winterfell via the passageway and join the Night’s Watch where all his crimes would be forgiven. Theon declined, fearing that if he appeared in Castle Black, Jon would slit his throat while he was sleeping. Theon believed that he had gone too far to come back. 

 After helping Sansa escape, he was also advised to join the Night’s Watch. He once again refused, thinking of himself as beyone repair and not worthy of forgiveness. He feared that if he showed up in Castle Black, Jon would kill him right away. Theon was not yet ready to face the judgement for his crimes.

Luckily for him, it was not as bad as he expected when he finally met Jon. ‘Though being angry with Theon at first, Jon appreciated what he did for Sansa and restrained himself from doing any harm to the betrayer. Jon finally forgave Theon and acknowledged him as a Stark, thus uplifting the emotional weight of guilt upon him. Jon’s kind words encouraged Theon to overcome his fear to go rescue Yara.

Theon had a safer option

After rescuing Yara, Theon could have chosen to go to the Iron Islands with his sister and take back their home, wait out the winter in a place the Dead cannot go. He said himself they should prepare a place for Dany to retreat in case they couldn’t hold the North and he would follow his sister’s command. But his heart was actually elsewhere. At Winterfell, where the fighting is thickest. Yara noticed the wish in her brother’s eyes, and she let him go where he wanted.

Gif: jaimelannistecr

He goes to Winterfell for the memory of Ned, fighting alongside the children of his foster father

No matter how Theon felt bitter about the Starks for being a ward in Winterfell, he admited that he saw Ned as his real father. 

When Theon faced Jon in Dragonstone, he was reminded that Ned was a father to him more than his biological father Balon ever was, that Theon had betrayed the memory of Ned.

However, Jon also offered an act of kindness and encouragement to Theon, he affirmed that Ned is always part of Theon, just like he’s a part of Jon. That was a huge morale boost for Theon.

Coming back to Winterfell, to the place that was his home for a handful of time, Theon is ready to defend the legacy of the honorable man who brought him up, alongside Ned’s children.

He is going to atone his betrayal to Robb by defending Robb’s brother(s) and sister(s)

Robb and Theon were more than just friends. They were almost like brothers. Theon followed Robb into the war and declared Robb his King. At the beginning, he whole-heartedly wanted to avenge Ned with Robb. He offered Robb his father’s Iron Fleet.

But he broke his promised and betrayed Robb’s trust. He led the Ironborn’s attack to Winterfell, sacked the castle and captured Bran and Rickon. His betrayal was the start for a chain of events that led to Robb’s eventual demise.

Robb was shocked, heart-broken, and angry when he learned about the news.

Theon then paid a high price for such crime. He was tortured by Ramsay and forced to abandon his identity. But he still remembered who he was, and was totally devastated when hearing of Robb’s death from Ramsay.

Oh, that’s right, Reek. Robb Stark is dead. Sorry. I know he was like a brother to you, but my father put a knife through his heart. How do you feel about that? (Ramsay to Theon, 4x02)

And Robb. Robb had been more a a brother to Theon than any son born of Balon Greyjoy’s loins. Murdered at the Red Wedding, butchered by the Freys. I should have been with him. Where was I? I should have died with him. (Theon, A Dance with Dragons)

When Robb was still alive, he was very protective of Bran. So I’m very glad that Theon volunteered to stay with Bran in the godswood to wait for the Night King. He continued what Robb left incomplete: protecting his little brother. 

Gif: rebloggy

Theon can also help to keep Sansa safe, the mission that Robb couldn’t finish. Robb started the war to free his father and sisters, but until Robb’s last days, Sansa was still a captive in King’s Landing. And she wept so much over Robb’s depature, even endured the pain of seeing her brother’s death ridiculed during the royal wedding. Sansa and Theon’s love and grief for Robb is one of the main factors that bond them together.

An apology to Ser Rodrik

One of the most heart-breaking moments in season 2 was when Theon beheaded Ser Rodrik. Coming to defend Winterfell against the Dead would be the most meaningful thing Theon can do to atone the crime he committed to the faithful master-at-arms of Winterfell.

Maester Luwin’s good heart finally pays off

In a brutal world like GoT, where the most ruthless and cunning people usually win, good, honest and compassionate people tend to be seen as weak, idiots and losers. But if in the end, Theon proves that a broken man like him can eventually amend his mistakes and become a brave and honorable person, the first person we should thank is Maester Luwin. He was very patient and never gave up on Theon, and used every chance possible to remind the heir of the Iron Islands of the goodness inside him. Maester Luwin even tried to interfere when Theon was beaten down and captured by his men to be handed to Ramsay, and was fatally wounded as a result. Doing the right thing, be the right kind of person is how Theon can pay tribute to Maester Luwin’s kindness.

Moreover, Bran was the Stark kid Maester Luwin spent the most time with. He had a lot of affection for Bran and tried to groom the little boy into a good lord. In his dying breath, the maester reminded Bran that there was still hope as long as he lived. Maester Luwin could rest in peace now if he knows the man whose heart he risked his life to stir back to goodness is now defending the boy who he loved and protect ‘till his last breath. 

To right the wrong he did to Bran

Bran always knew how to ask the right question. With braveness, he looked Theon in the eyes and asked if his surrogate brother in fact hated the Starks all the time. (Honestly, Bran looked like a professor asking his student a difficult exam question. 😂) It shook Theon, because no matter how resentful he was, he still cared for the Starks and longed to be one of them. But he had gone too far, so he kept his mask on, and tried to be as ruthless as possible.

Needless to say, Theon owed Bran an apology for taking Bran’s home and brutally chopping off Ser Rodrik’s head in front of his two little foster brothers, ignoring Bran crying and begging hopelessly.

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

This was perhaps Bran’s most traumatic experience up to that point, losing his home, being betrayed by someone he trusted like a family member, and seeing his faithful man horribly murder before his eyes. All in a day! Too much for a child as his age to bear.

At last, Theon has the courage to face the ghosts of his past crimes and amend for the horrible things he did by offering Bran his protection.

Gif: natalieedormer

For the love of Sansa

Is Theon in love Sansa? Since season 5, when their paths cross at Winterfell, this question has been raised. Even ‘though giving Sansa Jeyne’s Winterfell storyline was a divergence from the books, I beleve the show writers did this for a reason: to highlight Sansa’s relationship with both Jon and Theon. 

Like Jon, Theon longed to be seen as part of the Stark family and he endured the pain of feeling unworthy and being an outsider. As a child, he even dreamed of having Sansa’s hands in marriage, so that he could become Ned’s son.

He remembered a time when he had thought that Lord Eddard Stark might marry him to Sansa and claim him for a son, but that had only been a child’s fancy. (Reek, A Dance with Dragons)

Although it is not apparent in the books about Theon’s fondness for Sansa herself, the show made it quite obvious about his deep affection for her. Theon was totally broken and scared under Ramsay’s hands, he allowed himself to be treated like a loyal dog to his master, until Sansa came back to his life. She reminded him of who he was, his pride as a Greyjoy, that he was part of the Stark family. Gradually, she was able to convince him to pick up his strength again and break free from their abuser. 

Sansa has made the impossible possible. Theon’s embarked on his redemption journey since then. It tells how much of an influence she has on Theon. No matter what kind of love it is, familial, friendship, or romantic, it has to be really strong and true to create such a momentum for change in a person.

They’ve been through their darkest and hardest time together.

Gif: nemomurphy

Since Sansa had Brienne and Podrick by her side, Theon left halfway to go back to the Iron Islands. He was not confident that he could ever keep her safer than her family (Jon) could, and he was afraid that Jon would kill him right the moment he stepped through the gate of Castle Black.

Gif: nnymeros

Before they parted ways, Sansa gave Theon a hug as an act of forgiveness. She was the first Stark to forgive Theon for the crimes he committed to her family, and this meant a lot to him.

When Theon met up with Jon at Dragonstone, the first question he asked was about Sansa. He is concerned about his incomplete mission to protect her.

Gif: nnymeros

The thing I do for love

Gif: nnymeros

It was an emotional comeback for Theon. He is no longer the coward who is always scared and runs away. He chooses to face his past crimes and the people he wronged. He chooses to fight in the most dangerous place in the world, over his own safety in a place the Dead cannot reach.

For the love of Winterfell, his once home, the place where he grew up with his surrogate brothers and sisters, where he tasted his short-lived victory after sacking the castle and proclaiming himself Prince of Winterfell, where he suffered the worst traumas of his life as a punishment for his crimes.

For the love of Ned, the father figure who raised him to be an honorable person.

For the love of Robb, his brother and his King, who he swore to fight for, and yet betrayed.

For the love of Bran, the little brother he once wronged,

For the love of Sansa, the sister who’s been through the hardest time with him, who helped bring back his sense of self.

For the respect of Jon, the friend who always chooses to do the right thing in his eyes.

For Rickon, Maester Luwin, Ser Rodrik, and the two farm boys he murdered, …

There was a time it mattered for Theon to define himself as a Stark or a Greyjoy, which side he should choose, but once he is sure of his heart, it doesn’t matter how he calls himself anymore. What really matters is who he truly cares for, and who he wants to protect. That’s the power of love, the power that mends a broken person, the power that inspires and transforms him into a brave one.

If a man knows what he is, and remains true to himself, the choice is no choice at all. (Stannis to Shireen, 5x09)

Welcome back home, brother. Welcome back to the pack.

Gif: thesistersstark

Sansa was very sad when Theon didn’t go with her to the Wall. Now he’s back to her side in a difficult time when they are at the edge of life and death, Sansa rejoices. For her, it’s like getting back a long lost family member. The moment she embraced Theon, he was not only forgiven. He was accepted back to the pack, despite being no true wolf.

From now on, he was no longer seen as an outsider. He has the right to defend Winterfell and its people like a true Stark. He has become one of them. That’s the kind of acceptance he longed for.

Why do you love the Starks?

I wanted to be one of them.

Now you are truly one of them, Theon. 😢

Gif:  stormborns

Gif: gameofthronesdaily

Gif: yol101

There are certain things that only these two could understand and share with one another, because they suffered the same. To Sansa, Theon is like a brother, a best friend, who shares with her the most traumatic secrets. The affection Theon has for Sansa, I believe it’s a mix of familial love, profound friendship, adoration and a hint of romantic feelings for a lady. This is a deep, unique and special kind of bond that goes beyond pure romance.

Now and always.

Oh, that’s right, Reek. Robb Stark is dead. Sorry. I know he was like a brother to you, but my father put a knife through his heart. How do you feel about that? (Ramsay to Theon, 4x02)

And Robb. Robb had been more a a brother to Theon than any son born of Balon Greyjoy’s loins. Murdered at the Red Wedding, butchered by the Freys. I should have been with him. Where was I? I should have died with him. (Theon, A Dance with Dragons)

When Robb was still alive, he was very protective of Bran. So I’m very glad that Theon volunteered to stay with Bran in the godswood to wait for the Night King. He continued what Robb left incomplete: protecting his little brother. 

Gif: rebloggy

Theon can also help to keep Sansa safe, the mission that Robb couldn’t finish. Robb started the war to free his father and sisters, but until Robb’s last days, Sansa was still a captive in King’s Landing. And she wept so much over Robb’s depature, even endured the pain of seeing her brother’s death ridiculed during the royal wedding. Sansa and Theon’s love and grief for Robb is one of the main factors that bond them together.

An apology to Ser Rodrik

One of the most heart-breaking moments in season 2 was when Theon beheaded Ser Rodrik. Coming to defend Winterfell against the Dead would be the most meaningful thing Theon can do to atone the crime he committed to the faithful master-at-arms of Winterfell.

Maester Luwin’s good heart finally pays off

In a brutal world like GoT, where the most ruthless and cunning people usually win, good, honest and compassionate people tend to be seen as weak, idiots and losers. But if in the end, Theon proves that a broken man like him can eventually amend his mistakes and become a brave and honorable person, the first person we should thank is Maester Luwin. He was very patient and never gave up on Theon, and used every chance possible to remind the heir of the Iron Islands of the goodness inside him. Maester Luwin even tried to interfere when Theon was beaten down and captured by his men to be handed to Ramsay, and was fatally wounded as a result. Doing the right thing, be the right kind of person is how Theon can pay tribute to Maester Luwin’s kindness.

Moreover, Bran was the Stark kid Maester Luwin spent the most time with. He had a lot of affection for Bran and tried to groom the little boy into a good lord. In his dying breath, the maester reminded Bran that there was still hope as long as he lived. Maester Luwin could rest in peace now if he knows the man whose heart he risked his life to stir back to goodness is now defending the boy who he loved and protect ‘till his last breath. 

To right the wrong he did to Bran

Bran always knew how to ask the right question. With braveness, he looked Theon in the eyes and asked if his surrogate brother in fact hated the Starks all the time. (Honestly, Bran looked like a professor asking his student a difficult exam question. 😂) It shook Theon, because no matter how resentful he was, he still cared for the Starks and longed to be one of them. But he had gone too far, so he kept his mask on, and tried to be as ruthless as possible.

Needless to say, Theon owed Bran an apology for taking Bran’s home and brutally chopping off Ser Rodrik’s head in front of his two little foster brothers, ignoring Bran crying and begging hopelessly.

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

This was perhaps Bran’s most traumatic experience up to that point, losing his home, being betrayed by someone he trusted like a family member, and seeing his faithful man horribly murder before his eyes. All in a day! Too much for a child as his age to bear.

At last, Theon has the courage to face the ghosts of his past crimes and amend for the horrible things he did by offering Bran his protection.

Gif: natalieedormer

For the love of Sansa

Is Theon in love Sansa? Since season 5, when their paths cross at Winterfell, this question has been raised. Even ‘though giving Sansa Jeyne’s Winterfell storyline was a divergence from the books, I beleve the show writers did this for a reason: to highlight Sansa’s relationship with both Jon and Theon. 

Like Jon, Theon longed to be seen as part of the Stark family and he endured the pain of feeling unworthy and being an outsider. As a child, he even dreamed of having Sansa’s hands in marriage, so that he could become Ned’s son.

He remembered a time when he had thought that Lord Eddard Stark might marry him to Sansa and claim him for a son, but that had only been a child’s fancy. (Reek, A Dance with Dragons)

Although it is not apparent in the books about Theon’s fondness for Sansa herself, the show made it quite obvious about his deep affection for her. Theon was totally broken and scared under Ramsay’s hands, he allowed himself to be treated like a loyal dog to his master, until Sansa came back to his life. She reminded him of who he was, his pride as a Greyjoy, that he was part of the Stark family. Gradually, she was able to convince him to pick up his strength again and break free from their abuser. 

Sansa has made the impossible possible. Theon’s embarked on his redemption journey since then. It tells how much of an influence she has on Theon. No matter what kind of love it is, familial, friendship, or romantic, it has to be really strong and true to create such a momentum for change in a person.

They’ve been through their darkest and hardest time together.

Gif: nemomurphy

Since Sansa had Brienne and Podrick by her side, Theon left halfway to go back to the Iron Islands. He was not confident that he could ever keep her safer than her family (Jon) could, and he was afraid that Jon would kill him right the moment he stepped through the gate of Castle Black.

Gif: nnymeros

Before they parted ways, Sansa gave Theon a hug as an act of forgiveness. She was the first Stark to forgive Theon for the crimes he committed to her family, and this meant a lot to him.

When Theon met up with Jon at Dragonstone, the first question he asked was about Sansa. He is concerned about his incomplete mission to protect her.

Gif: nnymeros

The thing I do for love

Gif: nnymeros

It was an emotional comeback for Theon. He is no longer the coward who is always scared and runs away. He chooses to face his past crimes and the people he wronged. He chooses to fight in the most dangerous place in the world, over his own safety in a place the Dead cannot reach.

For the love of Winterfell, his once home, the place where he grew up with his surrogate brothers and sisters, where he tasted his short-lived victory after sacking the castle and proclaiming himself Prince of Winterfell, where he suffered the worst traumas of his life as a punishment for his crimes.

For the love of Ned, the father figure who raised him to be an honorable person.

For the love of Robb, his brother and his King, who he swore to fight for, and yet betrayed.

For the love of Bran, the little brother he once wronged,

For the love of Sansa, the sister who’s been through the hardest time with him, who helped bring back his sense of self.

For the respect of Jon, the friend who always chooses to do the right thing in his eyes.

For Rickon, Maester Luwin, Ser Rodrik, and the two farm boys he murdered, …

There was a time it mattered for Theon to define himself as a Stark or a Greyjoy, which side he should choose, but once he is sure of his heart, it doesn’t matter how he calls himself anymore. What really matters is who he truly cares for, and who he wants to protect. That’s the power of love, the power that mends a broken person, the power that inspires and transforms him into a brave one.

If a man knows what he is, and remains true to himself, the choice is no choice at all. (Stannis to Shireen, 5x09)

Welcome back home, brother. Welcome back to the pack.

Gif: thesistersstark

Sansa was very sad when Theon didn’t go with her to the Wall. Now he’s back to her side in a difficult time when they are at the edge of life and death, Sansa rejoices. For her, it’s like getting back a long lost family member. The moment she embraced Theon, he was not only forgiven. He was accepted back to the pack, despite being no true wolf.

From now on, he was no longer seen as an outsider. He has the right to defend Winterfell and its people like a true Stark. He has become one of them. That’s the kind of acceptance he longed for.

Why do you love the Starks?

I wanted to be one of them.

Now you are truly one of them, Theon. 😢

Trust each other

Theon volunteered to be with Bran in the godswood to protect him against the Night King. Bran accepted this offer, showing that he already forgave Theon and now he entrusted Theon with his life. This is a very dangerous task for both of them. 

Gif:  stormborns

Gif: gameofthronesdaily

When Theon offered this, Sansa’s reaction was clearly in focus. Sansa never saw the Dead herself like Jon or Bran, but she could imagine how risky it is to face the Night King. She was worrying for Bran, and for Theon. 

Gif: yol101

Later on, during the last calm moment before the storm, Sansa and Theon were shown having soup outside together. Many audience interpreted it as romantic, but I see it as trust, comfort and empathy. There are certain things that only these two could understand and share with one another, because they suffered the same. To Sansa, Theon is like a brother, a best friend, who shares with her the most traumatic secrets. The affection Theon has for Sansa, I believe it’s a mix of familial love, profound friendship, adoration and a hint of romantic feelings for a lady. This is a deep, unique and special kind of bond that goes beyond pure romance.

This is just my interpretation: I do think that this scene is not only about Sansa and Theon alone. Coupling with her concerned look during the war council (which was clearly in focus), Sansa is worried that Bran is putting himself in an extremely dangerous position, and Theon will be the one guarding Bran. So Sansa is entrusting Theon to protect their little brother. From her look, I would read it as “I trust you. Please keep Bran safe for me. And keep yourself safe too.” Theon finally has the right to protect Bran as a brother. He will do his best to keep Bran unharmed, Robb can rest in peace now.

Gif: captainmarvels

My sword is yours, in victory and defeat, from this day until my last day.

Am I your brother, now and always?
Now and always.

Theon has been through an incredible redemption arc. He’s grown from one of the most disliked characters to one of the most compelling characters. His journey proves that anyone can be forgiven, if he contrites and tries his best to amend for his mistakes. I hope that we would see more of the heroic acts from Theon, for as long as possible. After all the pains GoT have us endure, seeing a character like Theon stand up and be back to the good side is what the audience rightly deserve.

Related post: Theon’s homecoming journey

“Am I your brother, now and always?”

“Now and always.”

“My sword is yours, in victory and defeat, from this day until my last day.”

Theon to Robb, 1x10

So Theon’s return to Winterfell in episode 8x02 turned out to be much more beautiful and touching than I expected. I bursted into tears the moment Sansa ran into him, offered him a warm embrace and he hugged her back. The emotional weight of that scene, I could find no word to describe it. Alfie and Sophie totally nailed it with their brilliant acting. To me, it’s the best moment in S8 so far, because it is profoundly touching and very multi-layered. It’s not only about the bond between Theon and Sansa, but involves other the important people in their lives, both alive (Bran and Jon) and deceased (Ned, Robb, Rickon, Ser Rodrick, Maester Luwin). That’s the aspect I like about GoT, where characters are interrelated. Those who passed away still have an impact on the lives and decisions of those who remain. And in that sense, they are never forgotten.

Gif: thesistersstark

The lie he told himself

Despite his status as a ward, Theon was treated with kindness at Winterfell, and Robb considered him his best friend. But there was still distance between them.  Everytime Theon tried to prove himself a member of the Stark family, Robb unintentionally reminded him that he was not.

When Theon told Robb to wage a war on the Lannisters for attacking Ned, Robb told him it was not Theon’s duty to represent the Starks because it was not his House. 

When Theon shoot the arrow at the wilding who captures Bran, Robb was mad at him fearing that it would have endangered Bran’s life if he missed the target, and told him he didn’t have the right to carry such risky act. Theon was offended, because it was implied that Theon didn’t have the right to do so, because he was not considered as Bran’s brother.

Source: rebloggy

Robb didn’t mean to hurt Theon, but why was Theon upset about it? Growing up with the Stark kids, Theon longed to be one of them. He went with Robb to war, fought alongside Robb, declared Robb his King and offered to help bring Robb the Iron Fleet. He did all this to be accepted as a true family member.

When Theon was back to Pyke to persuade his father to join Robb’s side, Balon Greyjoy got mad at him for being more a Stark than a Greyjoy, and forced him to choose side. Theon was conflicted. He was about to send a letter to Robb to inform his best friend about his father’s plan.

Robb,
I hope this reaches you in time. Father has rejected your offer and plans to attack the North, raiding the shores and taking Deepwood Motte. Mobilize your army and make for the North before it’s too late. I’ll write again when I can.
Theon

Gif: rebloggy

But, in the end, he burnt the letter away, convincing himself that he could only be a Greyjoy since the Starks never saw him as one of them.

I could never be a Stark. Robb Stark always reminded me of that. […] It’s Ironborn, that I was born to be. (Theon to Ramsay, 3x04)

When Theon sacked Winterfell and proclaimed himself the Prince of Winterfell, Maester Luwin tried to appeal to the goodness in him by reminding him that Ned had gone out of his way to make Winterfell a home for Theon. He responded aggressively.

Yes, my captors were so very kind to me. You love reminding me of that. Everyone in this frozen pile of shit has always loved reminding me of that. You know what it’s like to be told how lucky you are to be someone’s prisoner? To be told how much you owe them? And then to go back home to your real father… (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But was it true? Or Theon was just lying to himself to make his act of betrayal less painful? Maester Luwin saw through him and told him he was just pretending to be a ruthless man, when in fact he was not. Not yet.

Deep down, Theon knew he loved the Stark and Winterfell as his family and his home, worsening the pains and guilt he bore in his heart.

I know who you are. I know what you are. Now answer my question. Why do you love the Starks?

“I…” Theon put a gloved hand against a pilar. “… I wanted to be one of them…” (The Turncloak, A Dance with Dragons)

His weight of guilt has been lifted

Right after Theon sacked Winterfell and committed horrible crimes, he started to feel guilty and horrified by his own acts. 

I’ve done a lot, haven’t I? Things I’ve never imagined myself doing. (Theon to Maester Luwin, 2x10)

But he continued to act ruthlessly to avoid being seen as weak. 

Being surrounded by Ramsay’s force, he was urged by Maester Luwin to escape Winterfell via the passageway and join the Night’s Watch where all his crimes would be forgiven. Theon declined, fearing that if he appeared in Castle Black, Jon would slit his throat while he was sleeping. Theon believed that he had gone too far to come back. 

 After helping Sansa escape, he was also advised to join the Night’s Watch. He once again refused, thinking of himself as beyone repair and not worthy of forgiveness. He feared that if he showed up in Castle Black, Jon would kill him right away. Theon was not yet ready to face the judgement for his crimes.

Luckily for him, it was not as bad as he expected when he finally met Jon. ‘Though being angry with Theon at first, Jon appreciated what he did for Sansa and restrained himself from doing any harm to the betrayer. Jon finally forgave Theon and acknowledged him as a Stark, thus uplifting the emotional weight of guilt upon him. Jon’s kind words encouraged Theon to overcome his fear to go rescue Yara.

Theon had a safer option

After rescuing Yara, Theon could have chosen to go to the Iron Islands with his sister and take back their home, wait out the winter in a place the Dead cannot go. He said himself they should prepare a place for Dany to retreat in case they couldn’t hold the North and he would follow his sister’s command. But his heart was actually elsewhere. At Winterfell, where the fighting is thickest. Yara noticed the wish in her brother’s eyes, and she let him go where he wanted.

Gif: jaimelannistecr

He goes to Winterfell for the memory of Ned, fighting alongside the children of his foster father

No matter how Theon felt bitter about the Starks for being a ward in Winterfell, he admited that he saw Ned as his real father. 

When Theon faced Jon in Dragonstone, he was reminded that Ned was a father to him more than his biological father Balon ever was, that Theon had betrayed the memory of Ned.

However, Jon also offered an act of kindness and encouragement to Theon, he affirmed that Ned is always part of Theon, just like he’s a part of Jon. That was a huge morale boost for Theon.

Coming back to Winterfell, to the place that was his home for a handful of time, Theon is ready to defend the legacy of the honorable man who brought him up, alongside Ned’s children.

He is going to atone his betrayal to Robb by defending Robb’s brother(s) and sister(s)

Robb and Theon were more than just friends. They were almost like brothers. Theon followed Robb into the war and declared Robb his King. At the beginning, he whole-heartedly wanted to avenge Ned with Robb. He offered Robb his father’s Iron Fleet.

But he broke his promised and betrayed Robb’s trust. He led the Ironborn’s attack to Winterfell, sacked the castle and captured Bran and Rickon. His betrayal was the start for a chain of events that led to Robb’s eventual demise.

Robb was shocked, heart-broken, and angry when he learned about the news.

Theon then paid a high price for such crime. He was tortured by Ramsay and forced to abandon his identity. But he still remembered who he was, and was totally devastated when hearing of Robb’s death from Ramsay.

Oh, that’s right, Reek. Robb Stark is dead. Sorry. I know he was like a brother to you, but my father put a knife through his heart. How do you feel about that? (Ramsay to Theon, 4x02)

Gif:  fuckyeahhousestark

This was perhaps Bran’s most traumatic experience up to that point, losing his home, being betrayed by someone he trusted like a family member, and seeing his faithful man horribly murder before his eyes. All in a day! Too much for a child as his age to bear.

At last, Theon has the courage to face the ghosts of his past crimes and amend for the horrible things he did by offering Bran his protection.

Gif: natalieedormer

For the love of Sansa

Is Theon in love Sansa? Since season 5, when their paths cross at Winterfell, this question has been raised. Even ‘though giving Sansa Jeyne’s Winterfell storyline was a divergence from the books, I beleve the show writers did this for a reason: to highlight Sansa’s relationship with both Jon and Theon. 

Like Jon, Theon longed to be seen as part of the Stark family and he endured the pain of feeling unworthy and being an outsider. As a child, he even dreamed of having Sansa’s hands in marriage, so that he could become Ned’s son.

He remembered a time when he had thought that Lord Eddard Stark might marry him to Sansa and claim him for a son, but that had only been a child’s fancy. (Reek, A Dance with Dragons)

Gif: nnymeros

For the love of Winterfell, his once home, the place where he grew up with his surrogate brothers and sisters, where he tasted his short-lived victory after sacking the castle and proclaiming himself Prince of Winterfell, where he suffered the worst traumas of his life as a punishment for his crimes.

For the love of Ned, the father figure who raised him to be an honorable person.

For the love of Robb, his brother and his King, who he swore to fight for, and yet betrayed.

For the love of Bran, the little brother he once wronged,

For the love of Sansa, the sister who’s been through the hardest time with him, who helped bring back his sense of self.

For the respect of Jon, the friend who always chooses to do the right thing in his eyes.

summary: Something interesting I just noticed (don't know if anyone mentioned) is that when Dany asks "who told you this?" Jon's response...
question: Something interesting I just noticed (don't know if anyone mentioned) is that when Dany asks "who told you this?" Jon's response is "Bran." Which prob did happen eventually but... literally not who told you Jon. He clearly didn't want to mention Sam to Dany after the events of 8x01. If he wasn't aware before, he's definitely aware now of her nature and trying to lessen the blow to prevent her lashing out further.
answer:
Hi there!

you might be a bit mistaken here. Jon’s immediate response is “Bran” and we can assume that Bran told him his vision, because otherwise Jon wouldn’t know the details of Lyanna’s death, but when Dany insists that Bran’s vision is not sufficient as proof, he tells her that Sam found the document that told about Rhaegar’s and Lyanna‘s marriage.

So, it is interesting, that Jon mentions Bran first. I think Jon would have kept silent about Sam, but he brought him up, when Dany demanded proof. For Jon, it all klicked into place when Sam told him, and maybe he thought that Dany would believe immediately as well.

Thanks for the ask!
